tickets.description:
WHO: Gabor Toth from Univ. of Michigan

Dear ESMF Support,

While working on the ESMF-SWMF coupling, I came accross
a number of problems. Although I managed to work around
the problems, they may be of interest to you. I am
using the latest public release 
2.2.0rp1.

Here is the list:

Defining a DELayout that does not cover the whole VM is
not possible.
Work around: It is possible to set the size of the DE
to zero.

If a component is created on some virtual machine but
the component is not yet initialized with
GridCompInitialize, then GridCompGet\(GridComp, vm=vm\)
provides a VM that is absolutely useless and any use of
the VM results in a segmentation fault.
Some of the system tests actually do this, but they do
not attempt to use the returned VM, so that's why they
do not crash.

If VMGet is called on a processor that is not used by
the VM, the code crashes.

Pointers must be nullified, otherwise
ESMF\_\*GetDataPointer does not work. It would be better
if the pointers were nullified internally.

Grid2 = ESMF\_GridCompCreate\(Grid1\) creates an unusable
grid.

ESMF\_BundleRedist does not work\!\!\!
It does not give any error message, but it does not
pass the data.

ESMF\_StateReconcile hangs, possibly because of bundles
in the state.
In the test it writes out a WARNING, in the more
complicated code it hung.

ESMF\_StatePrint shows the first field in the bundle
repeatedly rather than showing all the fields. But the
fields seem to be accessible.

The error flag is not returned from the run subroutine
of the component if the blockingflag=ESMF\_NONBLOCKING
is set.

It is not possible to read a logical value with
ESMF\_ConfigGetAttribute.
One has to read a string and figure out the logical value.

Best regards,

Gabor Toth

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

Best regards,

M. Amjad.

Shahdara Road, Quaid-i-Azam University Campus,
P.O. QAU-45320, Islamabad, Pakistan.

tickets.description:
WHO: Rupert Ford from ECMWF

Summary:

\- quickstart build failed because the my\_\(init/run/finalize\) routines required an intent\(out\) on the rc variable
\- linux/intel/mpich2 would not build for him because of a custom configuration in which gcc was not compiled with OPENMP


Hi,

I've downloaded ESMF release v4.0.0rp2 and compiled it on Linux \(ubuntu 
10.04\) using intel compiler version 11.1. I've used ESMF\_COMM=mpiuni for 
the moment.

What I find is that some of the sample codes provided in the release 
fail on compilation. For example the code in quick\_start does not 
compile. The type of error I get is ...

CplCompTemplate.F90\(32\): error \#7065: The characteristics of dummy 
argument 5 of the associated actual procedure differ from the 
characteristics of dummy argument 5 of the dummy procedure. \(12.2\)   
\[MY\_INIT\]
call ESMF\_CplCompSetEntryPoint\(ccomp, ESMF\_SETINIT, my\_init, rc=rc\)
\-----------------------------------------------------------^

The solution/workaround I have found is to make the rc argument to the 
my\_\* subroutines "intent\(out\)". The examples then compile fine.

I may well be doing something silly but I thought I would mention this 
problem just in case it is a bug \(in the code or the examples\).

The reason I am using mpiuni is that my mpich2 installation is 
incompatible with the ESMF defaults. If I set ESMF\_COMM=mpich2 then I 
get the following compile error ...

mpicxx -c -O -DNDEBUG -fPIC -pthread  -openmp 
-I/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/Infrastructure/Util/src 
-I/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/Infrastructure/Util/src/../include  
-I/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/build\_config/Linux.intel.default 
-I/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/Infrastructure 
-I/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/Superstructure 
-I/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/Infrastructure/stubs/pthread 
-I/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/include -DS32=1 
-DESMF\_OS\_Linux=1 -D\_\_SDIR\_\_='"src/Infrastructure/Util/src"' 
/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/Infrastructure/Util/src/ESMC\_Util.C 
-o 
/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/obj/objO/Linux.intel.32.mpich2.default/ESMC\_Util.o
In file included from 
/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/include/ESMCI\_VM.h:41,
from 
/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/Infrastructure/Util/src/ESMC\_Util.C:33:
/home/rupert/Downloads/esmf\_mpich2/src/include/ESMCI\_VMKernel.h:292:2: 
error: \#error - Compiler flags do not support OpenMP.

This is because my mpich2 installation uses ifort as the fortran 
compiler but gcc \(gcc version 4.4.3 \(Ubuntu 4.4.3-4ubuntu5\)\) as the c 
compiler and the version of gcc that I have does not support the -openmp 
option.

Is there a simple way round this? I've tried setting ESMF\_COMPILER to 
intelgcc but this does not make a difference - I still get the same 
error. I don't really want to recompile mpich2.

Thanks

\-- Rupert Ford

tickets.description:
WHO: Bobby Hunter


Bob and Cecelia,

Hi. I had mentioned to Cecelia that I was working on a test case that would replicate what we are doing with pWASH123-D and pADCIRC and I have it completed.  

What I have done is to use the ESMF\_FieldRegridDisjoint and ESMF\_CompFortranAndC system\_tests as a template. The test I have attached in the tar file runs using two unstructured mesh models with disjoint meshes. One model is written in F90 and the second model is in C++. 

Once you untar everything there is a DOC dir that contains a powerpoint that explains the test and the problems I'm seeing. In general, the test runs with 5.0.0 beta but the regridding is not correct, and with 5.0.1 beta it segfaults. I think my coding and use of the ESMF/ESMC functions is correct, but please double check \(especially the InterfaceIntCreate in user\_model2.C\).

I will be out of the office from Dec 23 - Jan 3, but would be available for a tele-con after the 3rd if you would like to discuss anything regarding the test case. Also, feel free to email anytime.

I'm sure you will probably want to move this thread to the ESMF support list, I just didn't know how it would handle attachments.

Thanks,

Bobby

tickets.description:
WHO: Gautam Bisht from Oak Ridge National Labs Brian Kauffman from NCAR.


Hi Gautam,

It was great meeting you the other day. The person to contact is Brian Kauffman \(I am cc'ing him on this message\). I already spoke to Brian about your work. The ESMF person to contact is Bob Oehmke. I am cc'ing him on this message as well. Bob - Guatam is working on incorporating a new 3D hydrological model within CLM that will pose new challenges in terms of regridding. We will need to do 3D regridding within an active component for the first time. Please keep cc'ing me on your exchanges, since I am very interested in getting new insights into how this project evolves.

Mariana


On 3/18/11 8:36 AM, Bisht, Gautam wrote:
Mariana,

I was great to get your suggestions/feedbacks, earlier this week at NCAR, regarding how to proceed with 3D grid mapping of CLM subsurface grid with 3D PFLOTRAN grid. You had mentioned that ROMS and POP have already incorporated a 3D mapping. I would appreciate if you could point me to the contact person doing 3D mapping for the ocean model. 

Also, if you could point me to the ESMF contact person who would help me in better understanding how ESMF regridding tool computes areas based on input/output grids that in lat/lon.

I look forward to your changes enabling CLM to run of cubed sphere, as they are released in future CLM tags. And, we will keep you informed as we proceed with 3D mapping between CLM and PFLOTRAN. Thanks for your help in hopefully making CLM a little-bit more computationally expensive in the future.

Regards,
-Gautam Bisht.

tickets.description:
WHO: Dan Kokron from the Global Modeling and Assimilation Office, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center


I am testing the regridding features in ESMF-5.2.0.  My current test
case involves regridding a 10800x5400 global LatLon \(LL\) field to
cubed-sphere \(CS\) grids ranging from c90 \(90x90x6\) to c2880
\(2880x2880x6\).  My CS grids are described by SCRIP format files.

I can report that all scenarios are working well.  I did have to modify
my ESMF sandbox to get things working though.

First:
The temporary ESMF grid description file \(.esmf.nc in ESMF\_Mesh.F90\)
created during the LL->c2880 operation is too large for the Classic
NetCDF format.  I chose to use NetCDF4 instead.

grep -in NC\_NETCDF4 Infrastructure/IO/interface/ESMC\_IOScrip2ESMF.C
481:    status = nc\_create\(c\_outfile, NC\_CLOBBER|NC\_NETCDF4, &ncid2\);
722:  status = nc\_create\(c\_outfile, NC\_CLOBBER|NC\_NETCDF4, &ncid2\);

Second: Feature request
ESMF\_Mesh.F90 automatically deletes the temporary ESMF grid description
file.  I have found that using this file instead of the SCRIP file in
calls to ESMF\_MeshCreate speeds the larger regridding operations by more
than 24x.  Please consider adding an option to ESMF\_MeshCreate to save
the ESMF Unstructured mesh version of a SCRIP file.

Third:
The regridding operation is not reproducible using different numbers of
processes.  Is this expected?

\-- 
Dan Kokron
Global Modeling and Assimilation Office
NASA Goddard Space Flight Center
Greenbelt, MD 20771
Daniel.S.Kokron@nasa.gov
Phone: \(301\) 614-5192
Fax:   \(301\) 614-5304

posts.text:
First:
We have added a netcdf4 flag. 

Second:
We don't think its a good idea to leave the temporary file. However, we have a task for 6.3.0 to parallelize MeshCreate. This should hopefully take care of the problem. 

Thrid:
We think the difference comes from the different order of the weight matrix. However, we haven't looked in depth whether aside from the order the matrix is that same from one number of processors to another.
posts.author: oehmke
posts.subject: #10 some observations regarding ESMF regridding

tickets.description:
WHO: Dan Kokron from the Global Modeling and Assimilation Office, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center

The GMAO uses a LatLon grid that has pole points that are centered on
each pole.  This is in contrast to the usual LatLon grid where the
poleward edge of each pole point represents the singularity.  I was
wondering if the ESMF regridding machinery can handle this GMAO LatLon
grid
\-- 
Dan Kokron
Global Modeling and Assimilation Office
NASA Goddard Space Flight Center
Greenbelt, MD 20771
Daniel.S.Kokron@nasa.gov
Phone: \(301\) 614-5192
Fax:   \(301\) 614-5304

tickets.description:
WHO: Jules Kouatchou from NASA GSFC

Hi Gerhard,

Sorry to bother you. I have two questions on ESMF states.

1\. I have two ESMF states A & B. I want to do A = B. Is there any
ESMF function for that? I want A to be a copy of B. A will be
manipulated and I do not want B to be affected.
2\. Assume that we have four ESMF states A, B, C and D that have
exactly the same fields. I want A to be the average of B, C and D,
i.e., A = \(B+C+D\)/3. Do you know ESMF function that can quickly
help me to compute A? What I have in mind to to individually go
over each field and do the average operation. If I can avoid that
it will be great.

Thank you in advance for your input.

Cheers,

Jules

\-- 
\-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Jules Kouatchou, PhD
Tetra Tech AMT                       |   Tel: 301-286-6059
NASA GSFC - Code 610.3               |   Fax: 301-286-1775
Greenbelt, MD 20771                  |   Jules.Kouatchou-1@nasa.gov
\-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Life is good\! It depends on how you perceive events unfolding around you.
\-------------------------------------------------------------------------

tickets.description:
WHO: Ben Foster of HAO at NCAR

Bob,

I would like to update my code to use ESMF v5.2.0r.
I was previously using esmf\_4.0.0rp1. I have successfully
built v5.2.0r on my 64-bit Linux machine using pgi-9.04,
but am having problems compiling my own module \(esmf.F,
see attachment\), which use-associates the esmf module, and
makes several esmf calls. Please see attached gmake.out.

I have already made a couple of changes to my source code,
namely "use esmf" instead of "use esmf\_mod", and changed
the call to ESMF\_Initialize. Now its complaining that it
cannot find the generic procedure esmf\_fieldregridstore\(\).
This is called 3 times in my sub esmf\_init \(see attached
esmf.F source file\). Considering the errors in gmake.out,
I'm thinking this might be too big a step to take right now,
or could at least use some esmf-expert help.
Can you advise?  Thanks,

PS:
The target for esmf.F in my Makefile:

esmf.o: esmf.F
$\(ESMF\_F90COMPILER\) -c $\(ESMF\_F90COMPILEOPTS\) $\(ESMF\_F90COMPILEPATHS\) \
$\(ESMF\_F90COMPILECPPFLAGS\) $\(FIXEDFLAGS\) $\(CPPFLAGS\) $\(FFLAGS\) $<

\--Ben
OS           =Linux

module my\_esmf
\!     use esmf\_mod
use esmf
use params\_module,only: gmlon,gmlat,glat,glon,nmlev,zpimag,nlon
use mpi\_module,only: tasks,lon0,lon1,lat0,lat1,nlevp1,ntask,
|  ntaski,ntaskj,nmagtaski,nmagtaskj,mlon0,mlon1
use apex\_module,only: gdlatdeg,gdlondeg \! \(nmlonp1,nmlat\)
implicit none

type\(ESMF\_Grid\),save :: esmf\_mag\_grid, esmf\_geo\_grid
\!
\! 3d \(i,j,k\) ESMF fields on geographic subdomains:
type\(ESMF\_Field\),save :: geo\_ped, geo\_hal, geo\_zpot, geo\_scht, 
|  geo\_adotv1, geo\_adotv2 
\!
\! 3d \(i,j,k\) ESMF fields regridded to magnetic subdomains:
type\(ESMF\_Field\),save :: mag\_ped, mag\_hal, mag\_zpot, mag\_scht, 
|  mag\_adotv1, mag\_adotv2 
\!
\! 2d \(i,j\) ESMF fields on geographic subdomains:
type\(ESMF\_Field\),save :: geo\_sini, geo\_adota1, geo\_adota2,
|  geo\_a1dta2, geo\_be3
\!
\! 2d \(i,j\) ESMF fields on magnetic subdomains:
type\(ESMF\_Field\),save :: mag\_sini, mag\_adota1, mag\_adota2,
|  mag\_a1dta2, mag\_be3

type\(ESMF\_RouteHandle\),save :: \! route handles for Regridding
|  routehandle\_geo2mag, routehandle\_mag2geo,
|  routehandle\_geo2mag\_2d
\!
\! geolon0,geolon1: lon0,1 for current task on esmf geo grid,
\!   excluding periodic points
integer :: geolon0,geolon1 

contains
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_init
\!
\! Called once per run at model initialization.
\!
integer :: rc
\!
\! Open esmf:
\!     call ESMF\_Initialize\(defaultlogtype=ESMF\_LOG\_MULTI,rc=rc\)
call ESMF\_Initialize\(logkindflag=ESMF\_LOGKIND\_MULTI,rc=rc\)
\!
\! Make magnetic and geographic grids:
call esmf\_create\_mag\_grid
call esmf\_create\_geo\_grid
\!
\! Create empty fields on geographic grid that will be transformed to
\!   the magnetic grid and passed as input to the dynamo. This does not
\!   assign any values.
\!
\! 3d fields on geo grid \(these will not have periodic points\):
write\(6,"\(/,'Creating ESMF fields on geographic grid.'\)"\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_ped ,esmf\_geo\_grid,'PED' ,nlevp1\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_hal ,esmf\_geo\_grid,'HAL' ,nlevp1\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_zpot,esmf\_geo\_grid,'ZPOT',nlevp1\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_scht,esmf\_geo\_grid,'SCHT',nlevp1\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_adotv1,esmf\_geo\_grid,'ADOTV1' ,
|  nlevp1\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_adotv2,esmf\_geo\_grid,'ADOTV2' ,
|  nlevp1\)
\!
\! 2d fields on geo grid:
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_sini,esmf\_geo\_grid,'SINI'     ,0\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_adota1,esmf\_geo\_grid,'ADOTA1' ,0\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_adota2,esmf\_geo\_grid,'ADOTA2' ,0\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_a1dta2,esmf\_geo\_grid,'A1DTA2' ,0\)
call esmf\_create\_geofield\(geo\_be3   ,esmf\_geo\_grid,'BE3'    ,0\)
\!
\! Create dynamo input fields on magnetic grid \(these will have the
\! single mag periodic point, but it will be zero after regridding\):
\! 3d fields:
write\(6,"\(/,'Creating ESMF fields on magnetic grid.'\)"\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_ped ,esmf\_mag\_grid,'PED'  ,nmlev\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_hal ,esmf\_mag\_grid,'HAL'  ,nmlev\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_zpot,esmf\_mag\_grid,'ZPOT' ,nmlev\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_scht,esmf\_mag\_grid,'SCHT' ,nmlev\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_adotv1,esmf\_mag\_grid,'ADOTV1' ,
|  nmlev\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_adotv2,esmf\_mag\_grid,'ADOTV2' ,
|  nmlev\)
\!
\! Create 2d fields on mag grid \(nlev=0\):
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_sini  ,esmf\_mag\_grid,'SINI'   ,0\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_adota1,esmf\_mag\_grid,'ADOTA1' ,0\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_adota2,esmf\_mag\_grid,'ADOTA2' ,0\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_a1dta2,esmf\_mag\_grid,'A1DTA2' ,0\)
call esmf\_create\_magfield\(mag\_be3   ,esmf\_mag\_grid,'BE3'    ,0\)
\!
\! Save route handles for grid transformations in both directions
\! geo2mag and mag2geo. FieldRegridStore needs to be called only 
\! once for each transformation before the timestep loop \(src and
\! dest fields are still required, so just use ped here\). Once inside 
\! the timestep loop, the same routehandle can be used for all fields 
\! that are regridded in the given direction.
\!
\! Geo2mag 3d fields:
call ESMF\_FieldRegridStore\(srcField=geo\_ped,dstField=mag\_ped, 
|  regridMethod=ESMF\_REGRID\_METHOD\_BILINEAR,
|  regridScheme=ESMF\_REGRID\_SCHEME\_FULL3D,
|  routeHandle=routehandle\_geo2mag, rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_init: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_FieldRegridStore for 3d geo2mag: rc=',i4\)"\) rc
call shutdown\('esmf\_FieldRegridStore'\)
endif
\!
\! Geo2mag 2d fields:
call ESMF\_FieldRegridStore\(srcField=geo\_sini,dstField=mag\_sini, 
|  regridMethod=ESMF\_REGRID\_METHOD\_BILINEAR,
|  regridScheme=ESMF\_REGRID\_SCHEME\_FULL3D,
|  routeHandle=routehandle\_geo2mag\_2d, rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_init: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_FieldRegridStore for 2d geo2mag: rc=',i4\)"\) rc
call shutdown\('esmf\_FieldRegridStore'\)
endif
\!
\! Mag2geo 3d fields:
call ESMF\_FieldRegridStore\(srcField=mag\_ped,dstField=geo\_ped, 
|  regridMethod=ESMF\_REGRID\_METHOD\_BILINEAR,
|  regridScheme=ESMF\_REGRID\_SCHEME\_FULL3D,
|  routeHandle=routehandle\_mag2geo, rc=rc\)

if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_init: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_FieldRegridStore for 3d mag2geo: rc=',i4\)"\) rc
call shutdown\('esmf\_FieldRegridStore'\)
endif
end subroutine esmf\_init
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_create\_mag\_grid
\!
\! Create ESMF geomagnetic grid, w/ lon,lat coordinates.
\! This is called once per run from tgcm.F. 
\!
integer :: i,j,k,n,localrc,istat
integer :: lbnd\(2\),ubnd\(2\)
real\(ESMF\_KIND\_R8\),pointer :: coordX\(:,:\),coordY\(:,:\)
integer,allocatable :: nmlons\_task\(:\) \! dim nmagtaski
integer,allocatable :: nmlats\_task\(:\) \! dim nmagtaskj
type\(ESMF\_VM\) :: vm
\!
\! nmlons\_task\(nmagtaski\) = number of mag lons per task in lon dim
if \(.not.allocated\(nmlons\_task\)\) allocate\(nmlons\_task\(nmagtaski\),
|  stat=istat\)
if \(istat /= 0\) call shutdown\('allocate nmlons\_task'\)
do i=1,nmagtaski
loop: do n=0,ntask-1
if \(tasks\(n\)%magtidi==i-1\) then
nmlons\_task\(i\) = tasks\(n\)%nmaglons
exit loop
endif
enddo loop
enddo
\!
\! Exclude periodic points \(1 point fewer for procs at east end\).
\! However, when the mag fields are created, they will be allocated
\! with the periodic point, which will be zero after regridding.
\!
do n=0,ntask-1
if \(tasks\(n\)%magtidi==nmagtaski-1\) then  \! east edge of proc matrix
nmlons\_task\(tasks\(n\)%magtidi+1\) = tasks\(n\)%nmaglons-1
endif
enddo
\!
\! nmlats\_task\(nmagtaskj\) = number of mag lats per task in lat dim
if \(.not.allocated\(nmlats\_task\)\) allocate\(nmlats\_task\(nmagtaskj\),
|  stat=istat\)
if \(istat /= 0\) call shutdown\('allocate nmlats\_task'\)
do j=1,nmagtaskj
loop1: do n=0,ntask-1
if \(tasks\(n\)%magtidj==j-1\) then
nmlats\_task\(j\) = tasks\(n\)%nmaglats
exit loop1
endif
enddo loop1
enddo
\!
\! Create curvilinear magnetic grid \(both coords depend
\! on both dimensions, i.e., lon\(i,j\),lat\(i,j\)\):
\!
esmf\_mag\_grid = ESMF\_GridCreateShapeTile\(
|  countsPerDEDim1=nmlons\_task, coordDep1=\(/1,2/\),
|  countsPerDEDim2=nmlats\_task, coordDep2=\(/1,2/\),
|  indexflag=ESMF\_INDEX\_GLOBAL,rc=localrc\)

if \(localrc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_create\_mag\_grid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_GridCreateShapeTile: localrc=',i4\)"\) localrc
call shutdown\('esmf\_create\_mag\_grid'\)
endif
\!
\! Allocate coordinates:
\!
call ESMF\_GridAddCoord\(esmf\_mag\_grid,
|  staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER,rc=localrc\)

if \(localrc /=ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_create\_mag\_grid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_GridAddCoord: localrc=',i4\)"\) localrc
call shutdown\('esmf\_create\_mag\_grid'\)
endif
\!
\! Get pointer and set mag grid longitude coordinates:
\!
call ESMF\_GridGetCoord\(esmf\_mag\_grid, coordDim=1, localDE=0,
|  computationalLBound=lbnd, computationalUBound=ubnd,
|  fptr=coordX, staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER, rc=localrc\)

if \(localrc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_create\_mag\_grid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_GridGetCoord for longitude coords: localrc=',i4\)"\) 
|    localrc
call shutdown\('esmf\_create\_mag\_grid'\)
endif

do j=lbnd\(2\),ubnd\(2\)
do i=lbnd\(1\),ubnd\(1\)
coordX\(i,j\) = gdlondeg\(i,j\)
enddo
enddo
\!
\! Get pointer and set mag grid latitude coordinates:
\!
call ESMF\_GridGetCoord\(esmf\_mag\_grid, coordDim=2, localDE=0,
|  computationalLBound=lbnd, computationalUBound=ubnd,
|  fptr=coordY, staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER, rc=localrc\)

if \(localrc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_create\_mag\_grid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_GridGetCoord for latitude coords: localrc=',i4\)"\)
|    localrc
call shutdown\('esmf\_create\_mag\_grid'\)
endif

do j=lbnd\(2\),ubnd\(2\)
do i=lbnd\(1\),ubnd\(1\)
coordY\(i,j\) = gdlatdeg\(i,j\)
enddo
enddo

end subroutine esmf\_create\_mag\_grid
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_create\_geo\_grid
\!
\! Create ESMF geographic grid, w/ lon,lat coordinates \(excluding
\! periodic points\). This is called once per run from tgcm.F. 
\!
integer :: i,j,k,n,localrc,istat,lbnd\(1\),ubnd\(1\)
real\(ESMF\_KIND\_R8\),pointer :: coordX\(:\),coordY\(:\)
integer,allocatable :: nlons\_task\(:\) \! dim ntaski
integer,allocatable :: nlats\_task\(:\) \! dim ntaskj
\!
\! nlons\_task\(ntaski\) = number of geo lons per task in lon dim
if \(.not.allocated\(nlons\_task\)\) allocate\(nlons\_task\(ntaski\),
|  stat=istat\)
if \(istat /= 0\) call shutdown\('allocate nlons\_task'\)
do i=1,ntaski
loop: do n=0,ntask-1
if \(tasks\(n\)%mytidi==i-1\) then
nlons\_task\(i\) = tasks\(n\)%nlons
exit loop
endif
enddo loop
enddo
\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: nlons\_task=',\(10i4\)\)"\) 
\!    |  nlons\_task
\!
\! Exclude periodic points \(2 points fewer for procs at each end\):
do n=0,ntask-1
if \(tasks\(n\)%mytidi==0.or.           \! west edge of proc matrix
|      tasks\(n\)%mytidi==ntaski-1\) then  \! east edge of proc matrix
nlons\_task\(tasks\(n\)%mytidi+1\) = tasks\(n\)%nlons-2
endif
enddo
\!
\! nlats\_task\(ntaskj\) = number of geo lats per task in lat dim
if \(.not.allocated\(nlats\_task\)\) allocate\(nlats\_task\(ntaskj\),
|  stat=istat\)
if \(istat /= 0\) call shutdown\('allocate nlats\_task'\)
do j=1,ntaskj
loop1: do n=0,ntask-1
if \(tasks\(n\)%mytidj==j-1\) then
nlats\_task\(j\) = tasks\(n\)%nlats
exit loop1
endif
enddo loop1
enddo
\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: nlats\_task=',\(10i4\)\)"\) 
\!    |  nlats\_task
\!
\! Create 2d geographic grid:
esmf\_geo\_grid = ESMF\_GridCreateShapeTile\(
|  countsPerDEDim1=nlons\_task, coordDep1=\(/1/\), 
|  countsPerDEDim2=nlats\_task, coordDep2=\(/2/\),
|  indexflag=ESMF\_INDEX\_GLOBAL,rc=localrc\)

if \(localrc /=ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_GridCreateShapeTile: localrc=',i4\)"\) localrc
call shutdown\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid'\)
endif
\!
\! Allocate coordinates:
\!
call ESMF\_GridAddCoord\(esmf\_geo\_grid,
|  staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER,rc=localrc\)

if \(localrc /=ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_GridAddCoord'\)"\)
call shutdown\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid'\)
endif
\!
\! Get pointer and set geo grid longitude coordinates:
\!
call ESMF\_GridGetCoord\(esmf\_geo\_grid, coordDim=1, localDE=0,
|  computationalLBound=lbnd, computationalUBound=ubnd,
|  fptr=coordX, staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER, rc=localrc\)
if \(localrc /=ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_GridGetCoord for longitude coords'\)"\)
call shutdown\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid'\)
endif

geolon0 = lbnd\(1\)
geolon1 = ubnd\(1\)
do i=geolon0,geolon1
coordX\(i\) = glon\(i\)
enddo
\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: geolon0,1=',2i4\)"\)
\!    |  geolon0,geolon1
\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: geolon0,1=',2i4,' coordX\(:\)=',
\!    |  /,\(8f8.2\)\)"\) geolon0,geolon1,coordX
\!
\! Get pointer and set geo grid latitude coordinates:
\!
call ESMF\_GridGetCoord\(esmf\_geo\_grid, coordDim=2, localDE=0,
|  computationalLBound=lbnd, computationalUBound=ubnd,
|  fptr=coordY, staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER, rc=localrc\)
if \(localrc /=ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_GridGetCoord for latitude coords'\)"\)
call shutdown\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid'\)
endif
do j=lbnd\(1\),ubnd\(1\)
coordY\(j\) = glat\(j\)
enddo
\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_create\_geo\_grid: lat lbnd,ubnd=',2i4,
\!    |  ' coordY\(:\)=',/,\(8f8.2\)\)"\) lbnd\(1\),ubnd\(1\),coordY
end subroutine esmf\_create\_geo\_grid
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_create\_geofield\(field,grid,name,nlev\)
\!
\! Create ESMF field \(2d or 3d\) on geo grid \(will exclude periodic points\)
\! If nlev == 0, field is 2d \(i,j\), otherwise field is 3d,
\!   and 3rd dimension is ungridded
\!
\! Args:
integer,intent\(in\) :: nlev \! if nlev == 0, field is 2d \(i,j\)
type\(ESMF\_Grid\),intent\(in\) :: grid
character\(len=\*\),intent\(in\) :: name
type\(ESMF\_Field\),intent\(out\) :: field
\!
\! Local:
integer :: rc
type\(ESMF\_ArraySpec\) :: arrayspec
\!
\! Create 3d field \(i,j,k\), with non-distributed vertical dimension:
if \(nlev > 0\) then
call ESMF\_ArraySpecSet\(arrayspec, 3, ESMF\_TYPEKIND\_R8, rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_ArraySpecSet'\)
field = ESMF\_FieldCreate\(grid, arrayspec, 
|    ungriddedLBound=\(/1/\), ungriddedUBound=\(/nlev/\),
|    staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER, rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_FieldCreate 3d'\)
write\(6,"\('Created 3d \(i,j,k\) esmf geo field ',a\)"\) 
|    name
\!
\! Create 2d field \(i,j\):
else                \! create 2d field
call ESMF\_ArraySpecSet\(arrayspec, 2, ESMF\_TYPEKIND\_R8, rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_ArraySpecSet'\)
field = ESMF\_FieldCreate\(grid, arrayspec, 
|    staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER, rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_FieldCreate 2d'\)
write\(6,"\('Created 2d \(i,j\) esmf geo field ',a\)"\) name
endif
end subroutine esmf\_create\_geofield
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_create\_magfield\(field,grid,name,nlev\)
\!
\! Create ESMF field \(2d or 3d\) on mag grid. This will include the
\!   mag periodic point, which will be zero after regridding.
\! If nlev == 0, field is 2d \(i,j\), otherwise field is 3d,
\!   and 3rd dimension is ungridded
\!
\! Args:
integer,intent\(in\) :: nlev \! if nlev == 0, field is 2d \(i,j\)
type\(ESMF\_Grid\),intent\(in\) :: grid
character\(len=\*\),intent\(in\) :: name
type\(ESMF\_Field\),intent\(out\) :: field
\!
\! Local:
integer :: rc
type\(ESMF\_ArraySpec\) :: arrayspec
type\(ESMF\_Array\) :: array3d,array2d
type\(ESMF\_DistGrid\) :: distgrid
\!
\! Get necessary information from the mag grid:
call ESMF\_GridGet\(grid, staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER,
|  staggerDistgrid=distgrid,rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_GridGet'\)
\!
\! Create 3d mag field \(i,j,k\), with non-distributed vertical dimension:
\! \(add periodic point in longitude with computationalEdgeUWidth\)
\!
if \(nlev > 0\) then
call ESMF\_ArraySpecSet\(arrayspec, 3, ESMF\_TYPEKIND\_R8, rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\)call shutdown\('ESMF\_ArraySpecSet 3d mag'\)

array3d = ESMF\_ArrayCreate\(arrayspec=arrayspec,
|    distgrid=distgrid,computationalEdgeUWidth=\(/1,0/\),
|    undistLBound=\(/1/\),undistUBound=\(/nlev/\),
|    indexflag=ESMF\_INDEX\_GLOBAL,rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_ArrayCreate 3d mag'\)

field = ESMF\_FieldCreate\(grid, array3d, 
|    ungriddedLBound=\(/1/\), ungriddedUBound=\(/nlev/\),
|    staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER, rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_FieldCreate 3d mag'\)

write\(6,"\('Created 3d \(i,j,k\) esmf mag field ',a\)"\) name
\!
\! Create 2d mag field \(i,j\):
\! \(add periodic point in longitude with computationalEdgeUWidth\)
\!
else                \! create 2d field
call ESMF\_ArraySpecSet\(arrayspec, 2, ESMF\_TYPEKIND\_R8, rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\)call shutdown\('ESMF\_ArraySpecSet 2d mag'\)

array2d = ESMF\_ArrayCreate\(arrayspec=arrayspec,
|    distgrid=distgrid,computationalEdgeUWidth=\(/1,0/\),
|    indexflag=ESMF\_INDEX\_GLOBAL,rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_ArrayCreate 2d mag'\)

field = ESMF\_FieldCreate\(grid, array2d, 
|    staggerloc=ESMF\_STAGGERLOC\_CENTER, rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call shutdown\('ESMF\_FieldCreate 2d mag'\)

write\(6,"\('Created 2d \(i,j\) esmf mag field ',a\)"\) name
endif
end subroutine esmf\_create\_magfield
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_set\_3dfield\(field,grid,fname,gname,f,
|  ilev0,ilev1,ilon0,ilon1,ilat0,ilat1\)
\!
\! Args:
type\(ESMF\_Field\) ,intent\(in\) :: field
type\(ESMF\_Grid\)  ,intent\(in\) :: grid
character\(len=\*\) ,intent\(in\) :: fname \! field name
character\(len=\*\) ,intent\(in\) :: gname \! grid name \('geo' or 'mag'\)
integer      ,intent\(in\) :: ilev0,ilev1,ilon0,ilon1,ilat0,ilat1
real         ,intent\(in\) :: f\(ilev0:ilev1,ilon0:ilon1,ilat0:ilat1\)
\!
\! Local:
integer :: i,k,rc
real\(ESMF\_KIND\_R8\),pointer :: fptr\(:,:,:\) \! i,j,k
\!
\! Get pointer to the field:
call ESMF\_FieldGet\(field,localDe=0,farrayPtr=fptr,rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\('>>> esmf\_set\_3dfield: error from ESMF\_FieldGet: rc=',
|    i4\)"\) rc
call shutdown\('esmf\_set\_3dfield:ESMF\_FieldGet'\)
endif
\!
\! Set the pointer with field values:
\! Input f has Z in first dimension, whereas the grid Z is 3rd dimension.
\!
fptr\(:,:,:\) = 0. \! init
if \(gname == 'geo'\) then
\!
\! Geographic grid: 
\! fptr\(i,j,k\) <- f\(k,i,j\), and exclude periodic points \(i=3->74 at 5 deg\)
do i=geolon0,geolon1
do k=ilev0,ilev1
fptr\(i,:,k\) = f\(k,i+2,:\) 
enddo
enddo
\!       do k=ilev0,ilev1
\!         fptr\(:,:,k\) = f\(k,:,:\) \! \(i,j,k\) <- \(k,i,j\)
\!       enddo
\!
\! Magnetic grid:
else
do k=ilev0,ilev1
fptr\(:,:,k\) = f\(k,:,:\) \! \(i,j,k\) <- \(k,i,j\)
enddo
endif

\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_set\_3dfield: field=',a8,' grid=',a4,
\!    |  ' 3d min,max=',2e12.4\)"\) fname,gname,minval\(fptr\(:,:,:\)\),
\!    |  maxval\(fptr\(:,:,:\)\)

end subroutine esmf\_set\_3dfield
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_set\_2dfield\(field,grid,fname,gname,f,
|  ilon0,ilon1,ilat0,ilat1\)
\!
\! Args:
type\(ESMF\_Field\) ,intent\(in\) :: field
type\(ESMF\_Grid\)  ,intent\(in\) :: grid
character\(len=\*\) ,intent\(in\) :: fname \! field name
character\(len=\*\) ,intent\(in\) :: gname \! grid name \('geo' or 'mag'\)
integer      ,intent\(in\) :: ilon0,ilon1,ilat0,ilat1
real         ,intent\(in\) :: f\(ilon0:ilon1,ilat0:ilat1\)
\!
\! Local:
integer :: i,k,rc
real\(ESMF\_KIND\_R8\),pointer :: fptr\(:,:\) \! i,j
\!
\! Get pointer to the field:
call ESMF\_FieldGet\(field,localDe=0,farrayPtr=fptr,rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\('>>> esmf\_set\_2dfield: error from ESMF\_FieldGet: rc=',
|    i4\)"\) rc
call shutdown\('esmf\_set\_2dfield:ESMF\_FieldGet'\)
endif
\!
\! Set the pointer with field values:
\! Input f has z-dim in first place, whereas the grid zp is 3rd dim.
if \(gname == 'geo'\) then
\!
\! fptr\(i,j\) <- f\(i,j\), and exclude periodic points \(i=3->74 at 5 deg\)
do i=geolon0,geolon1
fptr\(i,:\) = f\(i+2,:\) 
enddo
\!       fptr\(:,:\) = f\(:,:\) \! \(i,j\) <- \(i,j\)
else
fptr\(:,:\) = f\(:,:\) \! \(i,j\) <- \(i,j\)
endif
\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_set\_2dfield: ',a,' gname=',a,' min,max=',2e12.4\)"\)
\!    |  fname,gname,minval\(fptr\),maxval\(fptr\)
end subroutine esmf\_set\_2dfield
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_get\_3dfield\(field, fptr, name\)
\!
\! Get pointer to 3d esmf field \(i,j,k\):
\!
\! Args:
type\(ESMF\_field\),intent\(in\) :: field
real,pointer,dimension\(:,:,:\),intent\(out\) :: fptr
character\(len=\*\),intent\(in\) :: name
\!
\! Local:
integer :: rc
character\(len=80\) :: errmsg

call ESMF\_FieldGet\(field,localDe=0,farrayPtr=fptr,rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(errmsg,"\('esmf\_get\_field 3d field ',a\)"\) trim\(name\)
call shutdown\(errmsg\)
endif

\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_get\_3dfield: ',a8,' mlon0,1=',2i4,' nmlons=',i4,
\!    |  ' size\(fptr,1:3\)=',3i4,' fptr min,max=',2e12.4\)"\) 
\!    |  name,mlon0,mlon1,mlon1-mlon0+1,size\(fptr,1\),size\(fptr,2\),
\!    |  size\(fptr,3\),minval\(fptr\),maxval\(fptr\)

end subroutine esmf\_get\_3dfield
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_get\_2dfield\(field, fptr, name\)
\!
\! Get pointer to 2d esmf field \(i,j\):
\!
\! Args:
type\(ESMF\_field\),intent\(in\) :: field
real,pointer,dimension\(:,:\),intent\(out\) :: fptr
character\(len=\*\),intent\(in\) :: name
\!
\! Local:
integer :: rc
character\(len=80\) :: errmsg

call ESMF\_FieldGet\(field,localDe=0,farrayPtr=fptr,rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(errmsg,"\('esmf\_get\_field 2d field ',a\)"\) trim\(name\)
call shutdown\(errmsg\)
endif

\!     write\(6,"\('esmf\_get\_2dfield: ',a8,' mlon0,1=',2i4,' nmlons=',i4,
\!    |  ' size\(fptr,1:2\)=',2i4,' fptr min,max=',2e12.4\)"\) name,
\!    |  mlon0,mlon1,mlon1-mlon0+1,size\(fptr,1\),size\(fptr,2\),
\!    |  minval\(fptr\),maxval\(fptr\)

end subroutine esmf\_get\_2dfield
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
subroutine esmf\_regrid\(srcfield,dstfield,direction,ndim\)
\!
\! Args:
integer :: ndim
type\(ESMF\_Field\),intent\(inout\) :: srcfield,dstfield
character\(len=\*\),intent\(in\) :: direction
\!
\! Local:
integer :: rc
type\(ESMF\_RouteHandle\) :: routehandle
\!
\! Direction is either geo2mag or mag2geo. 
\! Use corresponding route handle \(module data\)
\!
select case\(trim\(direction\)\)
case \('geo2mag'\)
routehandle = routehandle\_geo2mag
if \(ndim==2\) routehandle = routehandle\_geo2mag\_2d
case \('mag2geo'\)
routehandle = routehandle\_mag2geo
case default
write\(6,"\('>>> esmf\_regrid: bad direction=',a\)"\)
|      trim\(direction\)
call shutdown\('esmf\_regrid'\)
end select
\!
\! Regrid: 
call ESMF\_FieldRegrid\(srcfield,dstfield,routehandle,rc=rc\)
if \(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) then
write\(6,"\(/,'>>> esmf\_regrid: error return from ',
|    'ESMF\_FieldRegrid for ',a,': rc=',i4\)"\) 
|  trim\(direction\),rc
call shutdown\('ESMF\_FieldRegrid'\)
endif
end subroutine esmf\_regrid
\!-----------------------------------------------------------------------
end module my\_esmf

tickets.description:
WHO: Tony Craig from CCSM

i am running into problems with esmf.  the detail are below.  but basically,
i'm calling ESMF\_TimeSet for yy=1900, mm=1, dd=1, s=0, with the calendartype
set to ESMF\_CAL\_GREGORIAN.  i am then trying to return the elapsed days
by calling ESMF\_TimeGet with a "d" argument.  that's returning something
i don't quite understand.  plus i'm getting esmf internal errors which i am pretty
sure is related to this section of code.   also, when i call the ESMF\_TimePrint,
nothing is written anywhere i can find.  any thoughts, thanks,

tony........

the code is:

write\(s\_logunit,\*\) subname,' tcx1 ',year,month,day,calendar
call shr\_sys\_flush\(s\_logunit\)
call ESMF\_TimeSet\(ltime,yy=year,mm=month,dd=day,s=0,calendarType=ESMF\_CAL\_GREGORIAN,rc=rc\)
if\(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call ESMF\_Finalize\(rc=rc, terminationflag=ESMF\_ABORT\)
call ESMF\_TimePrint\(ltime\)
call ESMF\_TimeGet\(ltime,d=eday,rc=rc\)
write\(s\_logunit,\*\) subname,' tcx2 ',eday
call shr\_sys\_flush\(s\_logunit\)
if\(rc /= ESMF\_SUCCESS\) call ESMF\_Finalize\(rc=rc, terminationflag=ESMF\_ABORT\)

the output i'm getting is

\(shr\_cal\_ymd2eday\) tcx1          1900            1            1  gregorian
\(shr\_cal\_ymd2eday\) tcx2       2415021

ccsm log file:

PET0.ESMF\_LogFile:

20111107 094637.739538 INFO     PET0 Running with ESMF Version 5.2.0p1
20111107 094655.283962 ERROR    PET0 ESMCI\_Calendar.C 1003 ESMCI::Calendar::convertToTime\(\) Input argument out of ra
nge ; Gregorian 0/0/0 \(1-12/>=1/>=-4800\).
20111107 094655.283982 ERROR    PET0 ESMCI\_Time.C 292 ESMCI::Time::set\(\) Input argument out of range Internal subrou
tine call returned Error
20111107 094655.283994 ERROR    PET0 ESMF\_Time.F90 1278 ESMF\_TimeSet\(\) Input argument out of range - Internal subrou
tine call returned Error

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

WHO: Researchers from the NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center \(e.g. Naomi Maruyama\) 

They want to use our regridding to go back and forth from field line data on a geomagnetic grid to a latxlon geographic grid. The hard part is representing their field line grid. I believe that it can be done by using a 3D unstructured grid.

tickets.description:
WHO: Alexander Pletzer from Tech-X Corporation

Hi Bob,

We're interested in the conservative interpolation capability of ESMF. We're wondering whether you'd be willing to run ESMF interp on a selection of structured ocean data, the grids vary from tripolar to rotated and shifted pole. Some grids need to be closed \(periodicity forced\), others need to have the connectivity at the pole be provided. Paul or I can send the data if you are interested.

We'd like to compare with the linear interpolation we have in libcf. I understand you are working or have implemented a python interface \(?\). Do you have tarball to download somewhere?

Thanks.

Best,

\--Alex

tickets.description:
WHO: Hanli Liu from NCAR

Hi Bob,

I have a quick question regarding ESMF: Does it do 3d interpolation between two different coordinate systems? Ben Foster used ESMF in TIME-GCM to interpolate between geographic grid and geomagnetic grid, but he said it's more like a bilinear interpolation in the horizontal direction \(so 2d\), because in TIME-GCM the two systems use the same vertical coordinate. For some ionospheric models, fields are defined on geomagnetic fields lines, so a true 3d interpolation \(trilinear is fine\) would be necessary. And I wonder if ESMF has the capability of doing it.

Thanks,
Hanli

tickets.description:
WHO: Mary Haley from NCAR 

Good morning Bob,

I gave my ESMF regridding talk this morning at MPI, with a good-sized group. Most of them are using the CDO to do their regridding. 

I got a regridding request from a user, which I'm looking into now. I thought you would be interested in hearing about it yourself, because it's a large grid and the CDO was having some problems with it. Here's the email:

many many thanks for the interesting lecture today morning. I actually have an application case for the ESMF-regridding and would kindly ask you to try whether it works.

In order to create ocean model bathymetrie we usually interpolate the Global Bathymetry and Elevation Data Set at 30 Arc Seconds Resolution \(SRTM30\_PLUS\) onto the MPIOM grid \(tri-polar curvilinear grid\). In our current simulations the MPIOM resolution is about 6' \(0.1°\). This corresponds to 3600x2392 grid points \(3602x2394 with halos\). So far the interpolation has been realized using CDO \(SCRIP library, conservative remapping\), but due to very high memory demands, the regridding was made piecewise \(for this purpose SRTM30\_PLUS data set has been divided into several 15° strips\) what might be error-prone.

The SRTM30\_PLUS Data \(srtm30plus\_v6.nc\) and MPIOM TP6M grid description \(TP6Ms\_3600x2392.nc, without halos\) can be found on the ZMAW ftp server:

ftp://ftp.zmaw.de/outgoing/fast

\--Mary

tickets.description:
WHO: Mary Haley from NCAR

Hi folks,

I have an ESMF regridding example I've created for regridding swath data from an HDF file.

One example worked fine under esmf-5.2.0p1 for all interpolation types \(bilinear, patch, conserve\). I get this output:

ellabell\[130\] cat PET0.RegridWeightGen.Log 
20120206 122345.227542 INFO     PET0 Running with ESMF Version 5.2.0p1
20120206 122347.270385 INFO     PET0 Running with ESMF Version 5.2.0p1
20120206 122353.218202 INFO     PET0 Running with ESMF Version 5.2.0p1


In esmf-5.2.0rp1, however, I'm getting this error for the conserve method \(patch and bilinear are fine\):

20120206 122523.294 INFO     PET0 Running with ESMF Version 5.2.0rp1
20120206 122524.344 ERROR    PET0 ESMCI\_Regrid\_F.C:126 c\_esmc\_regrid\_create\(\) Invalid argument - Src contains a cell whose corners are clockwise
20120206 122524.344 ERROR    PET0 ESMCI\_Regrid\_F.C:282 c\_esmc\_regrid\_create\(\) Invalid argument Internal subroutine call returned Error
20120206 122524.344 ERROR    PET0 ESMF\_Regrid.F90:383 ESMF\_RegridStore Invalid argument - Internal subroutine call returned Error
20120206 122524.344 ERROR    PET0 ESMF\_FieldRegrid.F90:771 ESMF\_FieldRegridStoreNX Invalid argument - Internal subroutine call returned Error


This is the command I used:

ESMF\_RegridWeightGen --source AusSnow\_src\_SCRIP.nc --destination AusSnow\_dst\_SCRIP.nc --weight Aus\_conserve.nc --method conserve --pole none --src\_regional --dst\_regional -i

Is there another option I need to include for the "conserve" method?

If you want to look at the files,  I've uploaded the two SCRIP files to our ftp:

ftp ftp.ucar.edu
<anonymous>
<your email as password>
cd pub/scd/haley
get  AusSnow\_src\_SCRIP.nc
get  AusSnow\_dst\_SCRIP.nc
quit

Thanks,

\--Mary

tickets.description:
WHO: Bart Nijssen from the Univ. of Washington

I would like to ask for advice for adapting a land surface model to use the ESMF superstructure so that it can be coupled more easily with other earth systems components. The land surface model in this particular case is written in C. The main question is whether it will make more sense to develop an ESMF-based wrapper \(superstructure\) for this code using the public Fortran API or whether it will make more sense to use the more limited \(and less extensively documented\) public C API.

Some background:

The land surface model in this case is the Variable Infiltration Capacity \(VIC\) model. The model is written in C and operates like most other grid-based land surface schemes in that there is no direct communication between the individual model grid cells. The model has mostly been used in stand-alone or offline mode, in which atmospheric variables \(from observations, weather or climate simulations\) are used as the boundary condition to force the model. The model has been coupled to other models in the past, for example MM5 and more recently WRF by way of a linking with CESM's CPL7. There is also a version of VIC which is implemented as part of NASA's LIS, which itself has some ESMF interfaces. The existing couplings have been ad-hoc and therefore difficult to maintain. Consequently, VIC model upgrades are difficult to perform and the coupled versions of the model are often much older than the latest version of our in-house code.

This is where ESMF would potentially be helpful. I am entertaining the idea of making the model ESMF compliant, in the sense of the working definition on the earthsystemmodeling web site. 

After reading through the documentation for ESMF, I am left with the question whether it makes most sense to write the wrapper or superstructure in Fortran and call VIC from there or whether I should use the C API. The reality is that at this time, most of the models that VIC will be coupled to are written in Fortran and most of the existing model components that use an ESMF superstructure use the Fortran version of the API. In addition, the Fortran API is better documented and appears to be more complete.

Any advice would be appreciated.

Best regards,
Bart Nijssen

\-----------------------------------
Bart Nijssen, PhD
Research Scientist Principal
Land Surface Hydrology Group \(http://www.hydro.washington.edu\)

Office: Wilson Ceramic Laboratory 111 \(http://washington.edu/maps/?WCL\)
Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Box 352700
Seattle, WA 98195-2700
nijssen@uw.edu

tickets.description:
WHO: Dr. Fabrizio Sassi from the Naval Research Laboratory

Hi Cecelia,

I have a complicated issue with a simple question. I hope the answer is 
simple \("yes, you can", "no, you can't"\), but I dread the answer will be 
more involved \("well..maybe you can do it, if ...."\). Without further ado:

We are writing a big proposal to NASA to couple WACCM-X \(the WACCM that 
extends to 500 km\) to an ionospheric model. The latter is the NRL-SAMI3 
model. For a number of reasons related to remapping between a 
geophysical grid \(waccm's\) to an ionospheric grid \(aligned along the 
Earth's magnetic isolines\), we are going to use ESMF in CESM. It is a 
big task and I have assembled a team of various people, including 
ionospheric scientists, climate people, and software engineers. Most of 
the interest in the ionospheric community is ultimately to have a 
community ionospheric model that is versatile and "plugable" for 
applications in space weather models. From a more scientific/speculative 
point of view, we are interested in the effect of the meteorology and 
climate of the lower atmosphere on the ionosphere/thermosphere. In 
particular, we are intersted in the effect on electron densities, in the 
E- and F-regions which affect the communications and navigation, both 
for civilian and military apps. I am the PI of this project, a task that 
is daunting and at the same time quite stimulating.

The main reason to use ESMF is that we heard it  allows 3-d regridding, 
while MCT \(the CESM default coupler\) is not a real 3-d remapper. So the 
first question is: Is this correct? Once again, we want to remap from 
the waccm's cartesian grid to the sami's magnetic coordinates. And, yes, 
I am aware that there will be a new dy-core for atmospheric components 
of CESM using a non-cartesian grid.

Then, the second question, and the one that is more involved has to do 
with the way ESMF works and what our needs are. WACCM-X has a time step 
of 5 minutes, SAMI3 has a time step variable between 1sec to 30 sec, the 
value used depending on the nature of the grid. In the context of MCT, 
it is my understanding that there is only one state vector from the 
atmosphere that is passed to the coupler and to be used by other 
components that sub-cycle using shorter time steps. This is the case, 
for example, of atm<==>ocn where the atm component has a time step of 30 
minutes: the same atmospheric fluxes and stress are used by the ocean 
during the many time steps that it has do to before it catches up with 
the atm. This is not a desirable way of operating in the thermosphere 
where you can almost call the molecules by name ;-\) . The problem is 
that there are ion drifts associated with the presence of electrical and 
magnetic fields that are quite sensitive to the background neutral 
conditions, as these determine the value of the conductivities, which in 
turn are used to invert the electric potential equation. Thus, if we 
have neutrals changing every 20-100 steps of the ionosphere, large 
discontinuities may follow.

One expensive solution is to reduce the time step of waccm-x. Another 
option that we would like to explore is if we can pass two state vectors 
to the coupler and thus let the ionospheric model do time interpolations 
between the two end points. Alas, I got to my big question: Is is 
possible under ESMF to pass two state vectors to the coupler \(that will 
handle remapping\) and thus to components that sub-cycle?

I am sorry for the long email. I hope that everything is well with you 
and your family. Say hi to Ricky from me.

thanks again for taking the time to answer my probably stupid question. 
If you prefer to talk by phone, let me know the time and the number 
where/when I can reach you.

Ciao\!

\-- 
Dr. Fabrizio Sassi
Naval Research Laboratory
Code 7646
4555 Overlook Ave SW
Washington DC - 20375
Tel: 202 767 3827
Fax: 202-404-8090

tickets.description:
WHO: Dennis Shea from NCAR

Hi Bob,

I have been testing the ESMF offline regridding via NCL.
Generally, the regridding tests has gone well. If I have had
questions Mary Haley has addressed them.

She is now on vacation and I have encountered two failures.
Both related to conservative regridding. \(Regridding via
bilinear and patch worked fine.\)

Not sure if you have the time or interest but ...

======================================================
CAM-SE:

One failure has to do with a test version of the CAM
\(HOMME unstructured grid\) to a  rectilinear FV1 \(Finite
Volume grid\). Since the next CAM dynamical core is HOMME,
I think it is important that this works correctly for
interpolation methods.

\---
\(0\) ESMF\_gen\_weights: 'ESMF\_RegridWeightGen' was not successful.

20120223 163322.077 ERROR    PET0 ESMCI\_Regrid\_F.C:146 c\_esmc\_regrid\_create\(\) Invalid argument- Dst contains a concave cell <\*\*

\---
PET:
20120223 150819.512 INFO     PET0 Running with ESMF Version 5.2.0rp1
20120223 161950.264 INFO     PET0 Running with ESMF Version 5.2.0rp1
20120223 163320.029 INFO     PET0 Running with ESMF Version 5.2.0rp1
20120223 163322.077 ERROR    PET0 ESMCI\_Regrid\_F.C:146 c\_esmc\_regrid\_create\(\) Invalid argument - Dst contains a concave cell
20120223 163322.498 ERROR    PET0 ESMCI\_Regrid\_F.C:282 c\_esmc\_regrid\_create\(\) Invalid argument Internal subroutine call returned Error
20120223 163322.498 ERROR    PET0 ESMF\_Regrid.F90:383 ESMF\_RegridStore Invalid argument - Internal subroutine call returned Error
20120223 163322.498 ERROR    PET0 ESMF\_FieldRegrid.F90:771 ESMF\_FieldRegridStoreNX Invalid argument - Internal subroutine call returned Error

\---
Test files are at:
ftp ftp.cgd.ucar.edu
anonymous
cd pub/shea/ESMF/CAM
get FV\_tst.nc                  <== 'target' grid \(lat\), \(lon\)
get HOMME\_tst.nc               <== 'source' grid
quit

=======================================================
ANTARCTIC SEAICE CONCENTRATION

This involved regridding a curvilinear grid ie: LAT\(N,M\), LON\(N,M\)
to a different curvilinear grid: lat\(n,m\), lon\(n,m\).

If interested, I'll make the data available via ftp.


=======================================================
Regards
Dennis Shea

tickets.description:
WHO: David Stuebe

As a result of a call with data services people, David sent the following mail:

Hi Cecelia

I don't want to distract this very productive group working on UGRID/GridSpec but I have some side questions for you about ESMF and your work that are somewhat tangential to their discussion.

I work on the Ocean Observatory Initiative Cyber Infrastructure project. We are interested in a generalized API & data model that allows optimization under the hood much like what you and I were advocating on the phone today.

We are very interested in FENICS and iTAPS for this purpose – are you familiar with these projects?
http://fenicsproject.org/
http://www.itaps.org/

Their model of entities, entity sets, tags and topology seems to allow the most general construction. These tools are really focused on the numerical modeling world, as is ESMF.

We are looking to leverage these tools outside the numerical modeling sphere as a means to support operations and transformations against a common data model. The goal is that we can write a transformation for the common model and apply it to point observations, structured and unstructured grid etc… without regard for feature type or structure.

From what you said today it seems that ESMF has some similar goals.

David

tickets.description:
WHO: Dave Kindig from TechX Corp

Ryan,
I am confused as to what ESMP\_GridCreate1PeriDim is doing when I do conservative regridding.
1\) Which dimension is it using for periodicity? I assume it is using the x coordinate, but I am not sure.
2\) The results I am getting for Bilinear with 1 periodic dimension seem correct. For example:

Source field                     Mask
1.0000  0.5000             \[\[0 0\]
0.5000  0.5000              \[0 0\]\]

RegridMethod Bilinear : PeriDim? False

1.0000  0.0000  0.5000
0.7500  0.6253  0.5000
0.5000  0.5004  0.5000

RegridMethod Bilinear : PeriDim? True

1.0000  0.0000  0.5000
0.7500  0.6253  0.5000
0.5000  0.5004  0.5000

3\) The results I am getting for conservative do not. For example:

Source field                     Mask
1.0000  0.5000             \[\[0 0\]
0.5000  0.5000              \[0 0\]\]

RegridMethod Conserve : PeriDim? False

1.0000  0.7500  0.5000
0.7509  0.6252  0.5000
0.5000  0.5000  0.5000

RegridMethod Conserve : PeriDim? True

1.5000  0.7500  1.1251
1.2509  0.6252  0.9377
1.0000  0.5000  0.7501

What simple thing did I miss\!?

Attached is the script used to create these numbers. It is currently set to create the conservative values.
Thanks, in advance for any help you provide.

\-- 
Ciao,
Dave


Dave Kindig
Research Assistant - TechX Corp \(www.txcorp.com\)
303-444-2386

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

tickets.description:
WHO: Patricia Michelle no affiliation provided.

I need ESMF to run GISS ModelE AR5.  I believe ESMF is building OK under OpenSuSE12.1 x64, but for some reason all tests throw this error into the xxxxxxxxx.stdio files.  This is likely impacting GISS because ESMF may not be finding what it needs at GISS build time.

./ESMC\_ArrayUTest: error while loading shared libraries: libmpi\_cxx.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
./ESMC\_ArrayUTest: error while loading shared libraries: libmpi\_cxx.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
./ESMC\_ArrayUTest: error while loading shared libraries: libmpi\_cxx.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
./ESMC\_ArrayUTest: error while loading shared libraries: libmpi\_cxx.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

I built like this:
\# export ESMF\_COMPILER=gfortran
\# export ESMF\_DIR=/usr/local/esmf\_4.0.0rp2
\# export ESMF\_COMM=openmpi
\# gmake 
\# gmake unit\_tests

tickets.description:
WHO: Brian Eaton from NCAR

Hi,

The recent 5.3.0 beta release added support for producing a grid from a
GRIDSPEC file \(for a single tile\).  I'm not having any luck find exactly
how a GRIDSPEC file is defined in the documentation.  Could you point me to
information detailing exactly what GRIDSPEC metadata I need to put in a
file so that it will be understood by the ESMF grid utilities?

Thanks,
Brian

posts.text: - **status**: open --> pending
posts.author: peggyli
posts.subject: #37 GRIDSPEC support

posts.text: Added file format sections for GRIDSPEC, UGRID and ESMF unstructured grid in the Offline Regrid application section at the HEAD and for the ESMF 5.3.0.   An email was sent to Brian on 5/4.
posts.author: peggyli
posts.subject: #37 GRIDSPEC support

posts.text:
There are several email exchanges with Brian.  To summarize it, first, as Brian pointed out, standard\_name is not a required attributes for latitude and longitude variables.  The required attribute for the coordinate variables is "units".  Also, there may be more than one set of coordinate variables defined in a grid file.  Therefore, there has to be a way to choose the  coordinate variables by user.   

Brian is also interested in the supergrid concert proposed by Balaji's GRIDSPEC proposal.  He wants to use it  to represent the grids with multiple stagger locations.   So, in addition to the short term solution in the offline regrid app. to support the selection of the coordinate variables, we are also looking into the supergrid and the way to support it in ESFM.
posts.author: peggyli
posts.subject: #37 GRIDSPEC support

posts.text: - **status**: pending --> open

posts.subject: #37 GRIDSPEC support

tickets.description:
WHO: Cédric Ody from   the Hydrographic and Oceanographic Department of the Navy, France

Dear developpers,

I am currently working at the oceanographic center of French Marine. I am interested in the ESMF regridding capabilities and I wanted to test them with the python interface.

I have successfully installed EMSF 5.2 on my Linux machine with gfortran 4.3. I had problems of installation with ifort compiler for which building of tests failed \(problem of standard library stdc++ \_ which is maybe not up to date on my system\).

With gfortran, tests passed and I was able to test the application ESMF\_RegridWeightGen successfully on simple netcdf files. Note that I had to add libnetcdff in the netcdf flags. I set up "standard" in ESMF\_NETCDF which may not be consistent.

So I wanted to check the results by using the python interface. I have python 2.7. However, the build of esmp fails even after adding the line ESMF\_LIBSDIR in the esmf.mk file: I get an issue saying that undefined symbols related to netcdf are found. And the esmp installation stops.

I have seen there are more undefined symbols in libesmf.so. So it is probably linked to my installation of netcdf?

Thank by advance for your help.

Cédric Ody

tickets.description:
WHO: Atanas Trayanov from NASA

Dear ESMF support,

I successfully converted GEOS-5 and MAPL to run with ESMF\_5\_3\_0 and produce identical results \(compared to our current operational version ESMF\_4\_0\_0rp2\).

However, in the process I came across a bug \(described below\):

GEOS-5 and MAPL still use our "own" location streams. In order to integrate variables on the exchange grid \(we call them tiles\) into the the rest of the system, we do the following

1\) define a distgrid based on the arbSeqIndexList of the tiles
2\) create a grid from this distgrid
3\) create a field from this grid and the fortran pointer to the variable

This procedure works OK. However, we often need to create another field \(based on the first one\) where we simply change the name. The procedure we use is:
1\) we query the existing field for grid and esmf\_array
2\) then we create a new field \(with the new name\), using the grid and esmf\_array from step 1

Step 2 fails for us. I am attaching a reproducer. I traced the error to gridIndex being different from array Index \(actally arrayIndex had correct value of 2 \(ESMF\_INDEX\_USER\), while gridIndex had a value of 0 \(ESMF\_INDEX\_DELOCAL\), although the grid was created with indexFlag=ESMF\_INDEX\_USER. Simply the call to ESMF\_GeomGet did NOT set the gridIndex - basically this is uninitialized variable error.

The same error exists in ESMF\_5\_2\_0rp1


I already have a workaround in MAPL \(to not create a new field if the name is the same\), but it would be good if this gets fixed.

-Atanas
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

tickets.description:
WHO: Charles Doutriaux from UV-CDAT

Charles,

Good point. There is ESMP.ESMP\_LogSet\(False\) call that should be invoked after ESMP.ESMP\_Initialize\(\) but the files will still be created \(I'm assuming nothing will be written in these files\). I think it is desirable to have these files as they provide more messages when something goes wrong.

Ryan: Is there a way to either specify the name of the files so different invocation of executables running simultaneously will not step upon each other? Thanks.

\--Alex

On 08/24/2012 10:10 AM, Doutriaux, Charles wrote:
Alex, Dave,

I recent versions of cdat I see some left over files:
PET0.ESMF\_LogFile

Is there a way to clean these up? What happen if I have 2 python scripts running at the same time is going to confuse ESMF \(since they will both have the same name\)?

C.

posts.author: rokuingh
posts.subject: #40 ESMP: UV-CDAT release schedule

posts.text:
Alex and Charles have implemented the solution to not create an ESMF log in UV-CDAT, this capability has been fixed.

This ticket is now tracking the next UV-CDAT release.  We are tracking this so that we can keep track of the ESMF recognition in this release.  Specifically we would like to see:
\- ESMF mentioned on the graphic on the UV-CDAT front page
\- ESMF capabilities explained in the release announcement
\- a retraction of the statement that "ESMF regridding does not work"
posts.author: rokuingh
posts.subject: #40 ESMP: UV-CDAT release schedule

posts.text:
UV-CDAT 1.2.0 was released on January 17, 2013.  They did update the front page graphic to include ESMF/P.  They did not add anything about ESMF in the release announcement \(that is not really their style\), and they did not retract their statement about ESMF regridding not working.  I would like to see two additional things on their website about ESMF:

\- ESMF should be mentioned on the acknowledgements  page
\- ESMF should be mentioned as a contributed project on the wiki
posts.author: rokuingh
posts.subject: #40 ESMP: UV-CDAT release schedule

tickets.description:
WHO: Dave Kingdig from TechX Corp


Charles,
As for what the default should be, I'll stay out of that. :\)

As to the plotting issue. Other than the strip where the grid is not closed, are there other problems? The two plots look remarkably similar otherwise.

Can you have a user set the keyword periodicity = 1? Note the two different regridding operations... tasInt and tasPer.

Here is an example:

import cdms2
import matplotlib.pylab as P
from mpl\_toolkits.basemap import Basemap as BM

cltnc = cdms2.open\('clt.nc'\)
tasnc = cdms2.open\('tas\_ccsr-95a\_1979.01-1979.12.nc'\)

tas = tasnc\('tas'\)\[0,0,...\]
clt = cltnc\('clt'\)\[0,...\]
tasInt = tas.regrid\(clt.getGrid\(\), regridTool = 'esmf'\)
tasPer = tas.regrid\(clt.getGrid\(\), periodicity = 1, regridtool = 'esmf'\)

bm = BM\(llcrnrlat = clt.getLatitude\(\)\[:\].min\(\), urcrnrlat = clt.getLatitude\(\)\[:\].max\(\),
llcrnrlon = clt.getLongitude\(\)\[:\].min\(\), urcrnrlon = clt.getLongitude\(\)\[:\].max\(\),   resolution = "i", projection = "cyl"\)

fig = P.figure\(\)
fig.add\_subplot\(211\)
bm.pcolor\(clt.getLongitude\(\)\[:\], clt.getLatitude\(\)\[:\], tasInt\)
bm.drawcoastlines\(\)
P.title\("tasInt = tas.regrid\(clt.getGrid\(\), regridTool = 'esmf'\)"\)
fig.add\_subplot\(212\)
bm.pcolor\(clt.getLongitude\(\)\[:\], clt.getLatitude\(\)\[:\], tasPer\)
bm.drawcoastlines\(\)
P.title\("tasPer = tas.regrid\(clt.getGrid\(\), periodicity = 1, regridtool = 'esmf'\)"\)
P.show\(\)

\--Dave


Dave Kindig
Research Assistant - TechX Corp \(www.txcorp.com\)
303-444-2386


On Wed 29 Aug 2012 04:53:59 PM MDT, Doutriaux, Charles wrote:
Alex,

I got MANY MANY unhappy users in my office lately about

1\. The switch from regrid2 to esmf as the default method \(broke a lot
of scripts\)
2\. esmf regridder being terrible

So I think in the light of these complaints we need to revert to
regrid2 being the default regrid method.

In the case of curvilinear/no rectlinear grids we should NOT
automatically switch to ESMF but rahter issue an erro that let them
know that they should set regridTool to esmf.

A simple regrid of our clt.nc dataset illustrate one of the many
reason I had "angry" users in my office.

See the attached png file on the left is ESMF regrid and on the right
the good old regrid2

I started to look into setting regrid2 back as the default but I got
really confused \(for example in  Lib/mvCdmsRegrid.py class CdmsRegrid
does have regridTool='libcf' as default\) I think it's better if you
guys revert it back, I'm worried about breaking it even more.

Sorry about this,

C.

tickets.description:
WHO: Kevin Raeder from NCAR/CISL/IMAGe/DAReS


Hi ESMF Help-person,

I've just finished trying out one of the demos,
and thought that you might like feedback from an outsider.

It wasn't smooth, which was partly my fault, but there are
improvements to the documentation that would prevent the mistakes that I made.

Someone familiar with the regridding tool pointed me to
http://earthsystemmodeling.org/esmf\_releases/last\_built/ESMF\_refdoc/node3.html\#SECTION03020000000000000000
which seemed like a good place to start.  I read through it,
and decided that I need the offline option, so I followed the link to
http://www.earthsystemmodeling.org/users/code\_examples/external\_demos/external\_demos.shtml.
There I tried to download the ESMF\_RegridWeightGenCheck using the 2nd CVS command onto bluefire.
The connection was refused.
I looked for more instructions and found advice on the link to
http://sourceforge.net/scm/?type=cvs&group\_id=38089
that I should try a CVS login first.
That connection was also refused.
I gave up on bluefire, and tried those 2 CVS commands on my desktop Mac.
That succeeded, so I copies all the files to bluefire.

The obvious place to go was external\_demos/ESMF\_RegridWeightGenCheck.
There I was happy to see a README file.  I tried executing the command
export ESMFMKFILE=/contrib/contrib/esmf-5.2.0r-64-O/lib/esmf.mk,
but 'export' was unknown in my shell \(tcsh\), and the 2 'contrib/'s seemed suspicious.
setenv ESMFMKFILE /contrib/esmf-5.2.0r-64-O/lib/esmf.mk   seemed to work.

Then I was happy to see that gmake appeared to build the executable.
I noted the bluefire caveats at the end of the README file, and 
didn't try to run gmake run, or execute the program on the command line.
I saw a script that obviously runs ESMF\_RegridWeightGenCheck, mpirun.lsf.ibmpjl.batch.mod,
so I started trying to run it.  Of course, there were a lot of problems
with that, because I wasn't supposed to run that script directly.
After a several hours of frustration, mostly because there was
almost no output from the batch job to tell me what might be wrong
and I thought that I was on the right track, I went looking for
a different way.

It turns out that I was supposed to run RegridWeightGenCheckDriver.pl, 
which wasn't mentioned in the README, and I only figured out by grepping 
for mpirun.lsf.ibmpjl.batch.mod in all the files in the directory.
I'm not familiar with perl, so a .pl file looked like something
I shouldn't mess with; maybe used for the build or execution.
I ran the .pl script \(eventually learning that I needed to run 'perl \[script\]'\) 
and it finally all worked.
Then I remembered that RegridWeightGenCheckDriver.pl had appeared at the top of
http://www.earthsystemmodeling.org/users/code\_examples/external\_demos/ESMF\_RegridWeightGenCheck\_ed.shtml
with the terse description that it's 'a top level driver'.
I never saw any instructions in any of the web pages or the README file about running it.

Once I was on the right track, another question came up.
In .../data I see ll\*.nc files for 1 and 2.5 degree.
Are there more regular lat-lon SCRIP files available for higher resolutions?
I could use 1/2 degree and maybe 1/4 degree.

One last question/concern: I looked at the metadata in
fv1.9x2.5\_050503\_to\_ne30np4-t2\_patch.nc
and it tells me that
:map\_method = "Bilinear remapping" ;
even though the method was supposed to be 'patch'.
Is this just a documentation error, or is the mapping in this file suspect?

Thanks for your attention and help,

Kevin Raeder
NCAR/CISL/IMAGe/DAReS

tickets.description:
WHO: Brian Eaton from NCAR

Hi Kathy,

I have taken a look at ScientificProperties\_CIM.xlsx and am working on how
to provide the attributes that the esmf interface recognizes.  My only
question about this is how stable do you expect these attribute names to
be?  If the names change how will I find that out?

I've also looked at the ComponentAttributes.xlsx file and have a couple of
questions.

. In the "Components" sheet you list AtmosKeyProperties as a subcomponent
of Atmosphere.  But in the CIM xml files that I've downloaded from
http://zonda5.badc.rl.ac.uk/site/public/repository I see that "Atmos Key
Properties" are a componentProperty rather than a modelComponent.  So your
hierarchy seems to be mixing these concepts, which I suppose just means
that internally you have some hardcoded information that knows the correct
CIM element type for the ESMF \*AtmosKeyProperties\* attributes.  That seems
fine, but the implication for me as a user is that I can't just look at the
CIM schema and arbitrarily specify metadata using ESMF attributes.  Instead
I need to look for an appropriate ESMF defined attribute which ESMF knows
internally how to translate into the CIM schema.  Is that more or less how
things are working?

. The "CAM Implementation" sheet contains information relevent to a
specific CAM version.  It seems to me that CAM should be responsible for
providing this information to ESMF, but I don't see what ESMF attributes I
would use to specify this information.  The specific information in this
sheet is out of date with respect to the CAM version used in CESM-1.0.4.

Thanks,
Brian

tickets.description:
WHO: Oliver Browne from the University of Edinburgh, Scotland

Hello,

I'm sorry to bother you; I feel sure this must be a trivial question, yet I cannot find a solution within the documentation, nor by looking through the ESMP/ESMF code.

I thought I would start learning to use ESMP by starting with a simple test.  I have ocean data \(lon-lat-depth\) on a 3D, logically rectangular, spherical, grid. I wish to move it to another grid that is identical apart from having its longitudes shifted by 1/2 a grid-cell.

I followed the structure of the tutorial, adapting it for 3-dimensions.  I am able to create the grids \(using GridCreate1PeriDim\), and populate a data field upon the input grid. However the regridding step crashes, complaining that I have supplied a grid with the wrong staggerloc.

The example on the python doc page is unfortunately only a 2D grid \(using \_CENTER and \_CORNER\).  This page suggests that the STAGGERLOC can be split into 2D and 3D types..

http://www.earthsystemmodeling.org/python\_releases/esmp.6.1.0.\_.\_.00.01/python\_doc/html/ESMP\_GridAddCoord.html\#ESMP.ESMP\_GridAddCoord

with the suffix of \_VCENTER or \_VFACE being needed for the 3D form, but this page says they are all for the 3D case..

http://www.earthsystemmodeling.org/python\_releases/esmp.6.1.0.\_.\_.00.01/python\_doc/html/ESMP\_StaggerLoc.html\#ESMP.ESMP\_StaggerLoc

I tried using the following cell-center/bound pairs \_CENTER/\_CORNER and \_CENTER\_VCENTER/\_CORNER\_VCENTER, both of which failed.  I have cell-centered values, and wish to simply provide cell bounds.  Any help on what STAGGERLOC option I should be using would be much appreciated,

kind regards,

oliver


\----
Oliver Browne

Land/Climate modelling specialist,
CESD at The Grant Institute,
University of Edinburgh.

\-- 
The University of Edinburgh is a charitable body, registered in
Scotland, with registration number SC005336.

tickets.description:
WHO: Jun Wang of NEMS

Hi Bob,
On a call with the NEMS group at NCEP this morning, Jun Wang had a few questions concerning 3D regridding in ESMF. Turns out that Jun's project is related to Naomi Maruyama's work, who you have been interacting with. I was wondering if you could open a support request for Jun and give her a brief intro to the ESMF regridding including 3D, with links into the ESMF docs, just to start the conversation with Jun. The interesting part here seems to be that regridding must happen every timestep, and potentially even regrid weight generation must happen on that same timescale - so performance of regridding becomes critical\! Thanks,
-Gerhard

tickets.description:
WHO: Manish Modani from Sci Tech Daresbury, UK

Hi\! 

I am from IBM & currently involved in porting the ESMF \(version 5\_2\_0rp2 \) on BG/Q at Daresbury System. 

I could compile and build the libesmf.a successfully \(For this I need to undo most of the work done for BG/L\). 

The jobs submission on the BG/Q at Daresbury is done through load leveller and it does not allow to run the jobs interactively. 

Hence the gmake check fails while running the jobs e.g. 
mpirun -np 2 ./ESMF\_StringUTest 1> ./ESMF\_StringUTest.stdout 2>&1 
cat: ./PET\*StringUTest.Log: No such file or directory 

Let me know if there is any other way to do the check. 


Thanks & Regards,
Manish


Manish Modani, Ph.D. | IBM India Pvt Ltd, 
STFC Daresbury Laboratory
Sci Tech Daresbury, Keckwick Lane
Daresbury, Warrington, UK
Mobile: \(+44\)7743754394

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed

posts.subject: #52 esmf_5_2_0rp2 on BG/Q !

tickets.description:
WHO: Till Rasmussen working on HYCOM CICE

Dear cray support

I am building a coupled HYCOM CICE using ESMF with 4 different compilers \(pgi, pathscale, gfortran and cray\) on a CRAY xt5.
I use ESMF 5.3

It builds on all 4 compilers and links on three of them.

The only one that does not link properly is the cray compiler.
The module list is attached

It has been compiled with the following deviation from standard.
setenv ESMF\_COMPILER cce
setenv ESMF\_ABI      64

It results in a number of undefined references within libesmf.a. Some of these refers to gcc which should not be used, however i cannot figure out where these links are set.

Can you help me to resolve the problem?
I link with the following:

ftn  -DMPI  -DUSE\_ESMF -O noomp         -I/data/tar/assim\_test//cray/ 
> -L/data/tar/assim\_test//cray/ -lassim 
> -L/data/tar/hycom\_cice/ESMF/esmfv5\_3\_0//lib/libO/Unicos.cce.64.mpi.default/ 
> -lesmf 
> -I/data/tar/hycom\_cice/ESMF/esmfv5\_3\_0//mod/modO/Unicos.cce.64.mpi.default/ 
> -I/data/tar/hycom\_cice/ESMF/esmfv5\_3\_0//src/include 
> -I/data/tar/munin-3/tmp/mpi\_default/cice-cray/cray-cray/cice-4.1/src/ 
> -L/data/tar/munin-3/tmp/mpi\_default/cice-cray/cray-cray/cice-4.1/src/ 
> -lcice -hbyteswapio   -o hycom barotp.o bigrid.o blkdat.o cnuity.o 
> convec.o diapfl.o dpthuv.o dpudpv.o forfun.o geopar.o hybgen.o hycom.o 
> icloan.o inicon.o inigiss.o inikpp.o inimy.o isnan.o latbdy.o 
> machine.o matinv.o mod\_archiv.o mod\_dimensions.o mod\_OICPL.o 
> mod\_floats.o mod\_hycom.o mod\_incupd.o mod\_mean.o mod\_pipe.o 
> mod\_tides.o mod\_xc.o mod\_za.o momtum.o mxkprf.o mxkrt.o mxkrtm.o 
> mxpwp.o overtn.o poflat.o prtmsk.o psmoo.o restart.o thermf.o trcupd.o 
> tsadvc.o wtime.o  -lcice -lnetcdf -L/data/tar/assim\_test//cray/ 
> -lassim 
> -L/data/tar/hycom\_cice/ESMF/esmfv5\_3\_0//lib/libO/Unicos.cce.64.mpi.default/ 
> -lesmf -L/opt/cray/mpt/default/xt/seastar/mpich2-cray/lib -lmpichcxx

Thank you 

Till

tickets.description:
WHO: helen He from the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

Hi Silverio,

A CESM user tried to use the ESMF libraries you installed on Hopper, and encountered the following error message:

==================
While trying to run the ESMF\_RegridWeightGen from
/global/project/projectdirs/ccsm1/esmf, I'm getting errors "ESMF\_ScripInq
Library needed by ESMF not present - - ESMF\_NETCDF not defined when lib was
compiled"

I was using the following command on compute node:

aprun
/global/project/projectdirs/ccsm1/esmf/ESMF\_5\_3\_0\_pgi12.5-0/bin/bing/Unicos.pgi.64.mpi.default/ESMF\_RegridWeightGen
\
\--ignore\_unmapped -s
/scratch/scratchdirs/gbisht/inputdata/lnd/clm2/mappingdata/grids/
1.9x2.5\_c110308.nc \
-d ../mkmapgrids/SCRIPgrid\_1x1\_boulderCO\_nomask\_c121206.nc \
-m conserve \
-w map\_1.9x2.5\_nomask\_to\_1x1\_boulderCO\_nomask\_aave\_da\_c121211.nc--dst\_regional
==================

Do you have any insights what might be the problem?

Thanks\!
Helen

tickets.description:
WHO: Fei Liu, ESMF

This ticket is used to track the initial conversation with Arlindo and the MAPL team at NASA Goddard. The main objectives of the collaboration are:
1\. Interfacing the NUOPC version of WW3 with NASA MAPL/GEOS5. This task could be coordinated through NUOPC with Tim Campbell and Gerhard.

2\. Explore use of ESMF regrid, XGrid, and location stream in MAPL/GEOS5.

tickets.description:
WHO: Tim Campbell from the Naval Research Laboratory 

In in process of setting up my regrid code to handle both spherical lon/lat and Cartesian coordinates I discovered that although GridCreate allows one to specify the coordSys flag there is no way to query a grid for its coordSys flag.  I suggest that coordSys be added to the GridGet options.  Also, it will be useful to support comparison operations with ESMF\_CoordSys\_Flag \(i.e., ==, \!=\).

Thanks,
Tim
