tickets.description:
WHO: Tom Clune from NASA

Hi Gerhard,

Hope all is well.

This question should probably go through the support desk, but I figured
I'd short circuit the process as it will need to be answered by someone
around in the early design days of ESMF.

I'm now adding a Mars Calendar to ModelE, and thus need to have
fractional seconds, which I previously deferred in my implementation.
  Interestingly they've decided to keep the notion of 24 hour days
(sols), so even if we were using ESMF classes, we'd be in trouble.  (I
see a hardwired SECONDS_PER_HOUR in the constructor for BaseTime.)   At
any rate, I wanted to understand a bit more about the reasoning behind
the design choices for Fraction.   I understand we want rational numbers
to enforce time ratios that must be commensurate, so no need to go into
that explanation.  But I am wondering why Fraction was represented as

w + n/d

rather than just

n/d

I've not given it much thought, but the latter would have been my first
thought on this matter.  Is there an advantage/simplification for
separating out the whole amount beyond the improvement in range?

My other question is what happens in practice.   So I've got resource
files and namelists that provide a bunch of FP values for various times.
   These get converted to Fracitons which for the planetary case are
likely to have largish denominators, as seconds are no longer such a
friendly unit of time.  And for some reason, GISS does not want to
redefine the second! :-)   I'm afraid that with just 2-3 sums, I'll end
up with denominators that exceed even the 64 bit representation used in
ESMF.   I can enforce some sort of rounding to keep this from getting
out of hand, and it really is probably only 2-3 independent numbers
being used in the end.   But has this been a concern in any largish
model that has multiple independent/weird time intervals?

Cheers,

- Tom



Thomas Clune, Ph. D. <Thomas.L.Clune@nasa.gov
<mailto:Thomas.L.Clune@nasa.gov>>
Chief, Software Systems Support OfficeCode 610.3
NASA GSFC301-286-4635
MS 610.8 B33-C128<http://ssso.gsfc.nasa.gov>
Greenbelt, MD 20771

Dear Gerhard,

I am sorry to both you, I have a problem when calling ESMF_CplCompCreate
routine on the NCEP wcoss gyre machine.  The ESMF version is 3.1.0rp5.
Could you show me what is wrong?  Thank you very much.

The simple test code is as:

!***********************************
     USE ESMF_mod

      IMPLICIT none

      TYPE(ESMF_CplComp)      :: CplGEFS

      integer, pointer :: pelist(:)

! Use 32 tasks.
!--------------
      PRINT*, '1, me =', me

pelist(1:28), rc = rc)

      END
!***************************************
The compiling file is:

-lw3nco_v2.0.3_d -lrt -lstdc++

/usrx/local/intel/impi/4.0.3.008/intel64/bin/mpiifort -FR $FINCM $FINCS

And the run submitted file is:

cd

When I run it, only a few PEs can pass the ESMF_CplCompCreate routine,

routine.

The error file showes:
ATTENTION: 0031-408  32 tasks allocated by Resource Manager, continuing...
ERROR: 0031-161  EOF on socket connection with node g2c10f

This type of code run worked well on the NCEP CCS machine and the Zeus
machine before.  Do you think the ESMF library installed incorredtly?

tickets.description:
WHO: Tim Campbell (NRL)



On 09/25/2013 07:29 PM, Tim Campbell wrote:> Hi Gerhard,
> 
> I did more investigation into the data dependent initialization issues that I was experiencing.  Specifically, the issues were
> (1) NUOPC_StateIsUpdated gives false positive for components that do not have any export fields;
> and
> (2) loopDataDependentInitialize hangs in the case of components defined on non-overlapping PET sets.
> 
> I have implemented fixes for both of these issues in the 6.2.0 version.  Attached is a gzipped patchfile with my changes.  I include the debugging lines (commented out), in case you would like to keep them.
> 
> The fix for (1) involves changes to NUOPC_Model.F90 and NUOPC_Mediator.F90 to handle the case of NUOPC_StateIsUpdate returning true, but the update count being unchanged.  This corresponds to a model having no export fields.  In this case, the model must explicitly set the InitializeDataComplete attribute.
> 
> The fix for (2) involves changes to the loopDataDependentInitialize routine in NUOPC_Driver.F90.  In the case of components defined on non-overlapping sets of PETs, there is a need to have "global" quantities computed as a synchronization in the loop over models and loop over connectors.  The changes I implemented work for the COAMPS case I am testing with.  You may find a better solution.
> 
> Cheers,
> Tim
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On Aug 20, 2013, at 3:21 PM, Tim Campbell wrote:
> 
>> Hi Gerhard,
>>
>> I'm wondering if any of the NUOPC prototypes test the data dependent initialization with components defined on non-overlapping sets of PETs.  The reason I ask is that COAMPS is hanging during this phase when I try to run in a concurrent coupling mode.  During the initialization phase not all PETs on which a particular connector are defined are calling into that connector's ExecuteRH phase at the same time.
>>
>> -Tim

WHO: Reinhard Budich  Max Planck Institute for Meteorology Strategic IT Partnerships, Germany

Dear Cecilia,

in the frame of the IS-ENES2 project we are trying to identify pieces of code in different European Earth System Models that are common across the models, and the area we start in is radiation codes.

Robert Pincus from Colorado State who helps us in this endeavor identified one of the problems at hand as the following:

"
We have identified some functionality shared by the radiation codes which we'd like to encapsulate. For the moment this includes two components used during initialization
*) file reading (netcdf, certainly, and whatever formats are used by Edwards-Slingo)
*) MPI broadcasting of the data read from files

as well as a uniform standard for error reporting.
"

We shared the impression that one of the very few places where we might find such functionality implemented in useable way might be the ESMF software suite. Since I know you for quite a while I was asked to contact you and find out about it.

So, here we are: Would you mind to get in touch with me to discuss this issue a bit!?

Thanks a lot!

Best Regards

Reinhard Budich

Max Planck Institute for Meteorology
Strategic IT Partnerships
Room 321
Bundesstr. 53
D-20146 Hamburg
Germany

Tel + 49 40 41173 369
Fax + 49 40 41173 616
http://www.mpimet.mpg.de/~budich.reinhard/
http://www.enes.org

WHO: Dusan Jovic from NOAA

Hi Gerhard, Matt,

When I compile NMMB on wcoss using ESMF 5.2 I get the following error.


[Dusan.Jovic@g10a1 Dusan.Jovic]$ svn co
https://svnemc.ncep.noaa.gov/projects/nems/trunk

....

[Dusan.Jovic@g10a1 Dusan.Jovic]$ cd trunk/src/

[Dusan.Jovic@g10a1 src]$ ./esmf_version 5.2_wcoss
+ cp conf/configure.nems.Wcoss.intel_ESMF_520rp1 conf/configure.nems
+ cp ESMFVersionDefine_ESMF_520rAPI.h ESMFVersionDefine.h
Use the ESMF 5.2.0rp1 library

[Dusan.Jovic@g10a1 src]$ make nmm

....

*module_DOMAIN_GRID_COMP.f90(3601): error #6638: An actual argument is
an expression or constant; this is not valid since the associated dummy
argument has the explicit INTENT(OUT) or INTENT(INOUT) attribute.   [0]
,defaultvalue=0                           &  !<-- default value to quiet
down ESMF if not set
--------------------------------------------^
compilation aborted for module_DOMAIN_GRID_COMP.f90 (code 1)
*

This is error is in the block of code that tries to get 'Use_Radar'
attribute from the import state which is never added to it. Gerhard, how
do we fix this? Matt, I think I asked you some time ago about this, and
at that moment I suggested to remove this whole block of code that deals
with Use_Radar attribute since it's not used anywhere in the code. Are
you still okay that?

Thanks,
Dusan

tickets.description:
WHO: Natalie Perlin Oregon State University

Hi,

 I recently updated my coupled code to run using ESMF_v5.2.0rp2 (and also tried ESMF_v6_2.0), and got internal ESMF errors when attempted to precompute FieldRegridStore handle.  I'm using pgi v.7.5 Fortran 90 compiler with mpich (pgf90, mpif90). As a first attempt, I tried to run 2-model system, one model per processors, and a coupler running on both processors. Attached are two sets of log files, one from each esmf version (producing similar errors...) The code fails after calling
ESMF_FieldRegridStore ( ).
PET0.ESMF_CCS_Log_esmf_v6.2.0
PET1.ESMF_CCS_Log_esmf_v6.2.0
PET0.ESMF_CCS_Log_esmf5.2.0rp2
PET1.ESMF_CCS_Log_esmf5.2.0rp2

Similar code successfully ran with ESMF_5_1_0, when I added a keyword   "regridScheme=ESMF_REGRID_SCHEME_NATIVE" to the ESMF_FieldRegridStore call. This keyword is depreciated in newer versions of ESMF, however ...

  I use lat/lon coordinates to set up grids in both models, and the printouts show normal values/range. Is there anything else to be checked, maybe with CoordSys_Flag?.. I did try both ESMF_COORDSYS_CART, or ESMF_COORSYS_SPH_DEG, with no difference.

 Attached are also basic pieces of code related to the coupled system, that show how the grids and fields were created. The files are:
esmf_coupler.h (a main routine),
esmf_roms.F (model #1, runs on PET0)
esmf_coamps.F (model #2, runs on PET1)
esmf_cpl.F (coupler, runs on both PET0 and PET1).

I will greatly appreciate any suggestions on the issue, what could be tested or checked to diagnose the FieldRegridStore problem!..

Thank you,
Natalie.

-- 
--------------------------------------------------
Dr. Natalie Perlin
College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences
Oregon State University
104 CEOAS Admin. Bldg.
Corvallis, OR 97331-5503
 ph: 541-737-8191 fax: 541-737-2064
 e-mail: nperlin@coas.oregonstate.edu
--------------------------------------------------

tickets.description:
WHO: Rupert Gladstone

Dear Gerhard and co., just a bit more information about the error reporting issue when outputting to netcdf (see ticket #124).

I have since recompiled ESMF with a new netcdf installation and the netcdf outputting seems to work now from the coupled flow example.  I can still induce it to fail, by simply running the model without having removed the netcdf files from the previous run, and again I get a failure with no error reporting.  So I have induced 2 different types of failure when trying to use netcdf for outputting, and in neither case did I get any error messages about the problems.

In contrast, if I set the output format to binary and induce a failure, I get a meaningful error message (e.g. "write_mpiio_real: after call to file_write_all:MPI_ERR_READ_ONLY: file is read only").

So I guess there needs to be some error reporting added to ESMF_FieldWrite or its subroutines for the case of netcdf formatted output.

Regards,
Rupert

        I am Yichen Lu, a researcher from University of Pennsylvania. I just downloaded the esmf_5_2_0rp2_src.tar.gz. tickets.description:
WHO: Gautam Bisht Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

Hi,

While attempting to map a CESM grid onto a regional grid via conservative mapping, I noticed that frac_a (fraction of source mesh) is greater than 1.0 for few cells. Can frac_a > 1.0? Any insights on how to resolve this are much appreciated.

Thanks,
-Gautam.

tickets.description:
WHO: Damien Irving  University of Melbourne

Hi,

I have a research problem where I have data on a regular global latitude/longitude grid (1 deg by 1 deg resolution). 

I need to shift the location of the poles and then regrid my original data so that it is regularly spaced in this new displaced pole world. I have written a script from scratch to perform this regridding, using Euler angles and the transformation matrix described here: http://www.ocgy.ubc.ca/~yzq/books/MOM3/s4node19.html. 

I was wondering, however, whether the ESMPy package has the functionality to perform such a task? (i.e. I was hoping to validate my results this way).


Regards,
Damien
 

-- 
Damien Irving
PhD Candidate
School of Earth Sciences
The University of Melbourne

Secretary, Australian Meteorological and Oceanographic Society (AMOS)

Ph: +61 3 8344 6911
Blog: http://drclimate.wordpress.com/
Twitter: @DrClimate
Research: http://www.researcherid.com/rid/A-1479-2012
_______________________________________________

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: Ryan O'Kuinghttons --> oehmke
posts.author: oehmke
posts.subject: #139 ESMP displaced pole functionality

tickets.description:
WHO: George Markomanolis Barcelona Supercomputing Center

Dear all,

I have one question about ESMF. First of all to clarify that I am new to ESMF community. So I just updated the NMMB model here at BSC to use ESMF 6.1.1 and works pretty good. My question is that during ESMF_Finalize(), I have some messages of " ESMF_LogFlush(): ESMF_Log not open -- cannot ESMF_LogFlush()". However, there is no hanging but I think while we scale it wouldn't be that good.

So I have commented all the ESMF_LogWrite calls across the code because we don't want them and I have seen some studies dome from ESMF people about the performance issues while we scale the number of the processors. The variable logkindflag during ESMF_Initialize() is equal to ESMF_LOGKIND_NONE and I have tried to change the values of ESMF_LogSet() or even not to call it at all but again I have the same message during ESMF_Finalize(). From the error I assume I have to use ESMF_LogOpen but I don't want to use ESMF log files at all, is it a way to avoid this message? Do I miss something?

ESMF verion 6.1.1
ifort version 13.0.1
NMMB v2.0
Priority: normal

Thanks in advance,
George Markomanolis

-- 
______________________________________________________________________

George Markomanolis
Earth Sciences Department
Barcelona Supercomputing Center - Centro Nacional de Supercomputación
Edifici Nexus II
c/ Jordi Girona 29, 08034 Barcelona, Spain

Phone: +34 934134073 Fax: +34 934137721
Mail to:georgios.markomanolis@bsc.es

BSC web page:http://www.bsc.es/
______________________________________________________________________

posts.text: - **status**: No-First-Contact --> Open
posts.author: w6ws
posts.subject: #140 ESMF 6.1.1 and turn off logging

posts.text: The extraneous messages are reproducable with the current trunk.  I emailed George that I will look into a fix for the issue for him.

posts.author: w6ws
posts.subject: #140 ESMF 6.1.1 and turn off logging

posts.text: Mod made to eliminate the extraneous message on the default log, when ESMF_LOGKIND_NONE was specified.  Emailed George to try the ESMF_6_3_0_beta_snapshot_06 tag and let us know how it works.  Pending per 11/14/2013 ticket meeting.

tickets.description:
WHO: Mike Hobson Met Office Hadley Centre

Hi,
 
My name is Mike Hobson and I work for the Met Office. We are continuing to assess whether we can use ESMF as the basis or the framework for the replacement to our Weather and Climate model.
 
In order to get reasonable scaling properties on large processor counts, we will be switching to a non longitude-latitude grid. One of the grids being considered is based on a truncated icosahedron - 12 pentagons surrounded by 20 hexagons (looks like a soccer ball). The hexagons are then subdivided into smaller hexagons to increase the resolution.
 
I am trying to define a field on an ESMF Mesh that describes this grid, but I can only set the ESMF_MESHELEMTYPE to triangles or quads - which means I can't represent my pentagons and hexagons directly with an ESMF Mesh (I could break down the pentagons and hexagons into smaller triangles, but this will make the maths of the model very messy/difficult).
 
Do you know if there are any plans for ESMF to support Meshes with pentagonal and hexagonal element types in the future?
 
Thanks,
 
Mike Hobson
Met Office Hadley Centre FitzRoy Road Exeter Devon EX1 3PB United Kingdom
Tel: +44 (0) 1392 884847
E-mail: mike.hobson@metoffice.gov.uk Website: http://www.metoffice.gov.uk
tickets.summary: ESMF mesh support for pentagonal and hexagonal elements

tickets.description:
WHO: Hanli Liu from NCAR

Dear Bob,

As you know, the new CAM and WACCM dycore uses cubed sphere. Although the code (dp_coupling) provides a way to map between physics columns (chunks) and the cubed sphere columns (blocks), there doesn't seem to be a straightforward way of mapping between cubed sphere and lat-lon. For some of the coupled components we are developing, we do need to map variables to lat-lon. From reading ESMF, it seems it has the capability of doing 2d remapping between logically rectangular grids, to which cubed sphere grid (and of course lat-lon) belongs. So I would think this is something that we can achieve using ESMF (or probably it's already done?). From previous communications, I understand that the 3D remapping only works for cartesian. In the problem we are dealing now, the vertical grids of the cubed sphere and lat-lon are the same (pressure levels), so 2D remapping should suffice.

Please let me know what you think. If you prefer, I can give you a ring and we can talk about it.

Thanks,
Hanli

posts.text: - **status**: No-First-Contact --> Open
posts.author: oehmke
posts.subject: #145 cubed sphere and lat-lon grids

tickets.description:
From: Tony Craig UCAR

    according to the documentation, the XGrid cannot have the same grid on
    side A and B.  in that case, should a rearranger and manual merging be used instead?  this
    seems like an unnecessary restriction which would limit the flexiblity of the XGrid.  i can
    see cases (like in CESM) where sometimes models are run on unique grids and sometimes
    on the same grid.  we would like to be able to leverage the same code.  also, for cases where
    users want to map using some other method than local area conservative, it might be nice
    to still use the XGrid to exchange data that ends up on the same grid.  but i'm sure i'm missing
    90% of the big picture still.


The limitation 'XGrid cannot have the same Grid on side A and B' really should be 'XGrid cannot have same Grid on side A and B when side A and B are on same set of processors and the Grid have identical distribution on those processors.' It's rather counter-productive in this case to use XGrid because the weight matrix is an identity matrix. One can simply reference/copy the Field data on A or B side. Further more, this limitation is not a limitation in XGrid creation, it's due to that we don't have collective GridMatch() and MeshMatch() calls that allow FieldRegridStore() to pick the right pair of Grid/Mesh to calculate the routehandle.  i.e. You can call ESMF_XGridCreate() without problem for such a scenario, however ESMF_FieldRegridStore() through XGrid reports this error because it cannot automatically determine if that Grid is on side A or B for pair-wise routehandle generation. This limitation is easy to eliminate.  I think for CESM this is not a problem because side A and B are on different processors with different distribution. But if this becomes a problem for CESM application, I can remove this limitation by adding additional check during ESMF_FieldRegridStore() through XGrid.
tickets.summary: Remove limitation in XGrid working with identical src/dst Grid on same processors.

posts.text: Fei needs to improve documentation and schedule time to remove this limitation.
posts.author: feiliu
posts.subject: #146 Remove limitation in XGrid working with identical src/dst Grid on same processors.

tickets.description:
WHO: Dave Gochis NCAR

Hi Bob,

It was great to meet you in person last Fri.  I'm excited for the new project as well and the chance to continue working with you folks.  I did get a little time to tinker some more with our latest regridding application which had some odd artifacts in it.  Not sure if you still have time to take a look at this but I've attached the image of the temperature field that was regridded from one wrfoutput grid to another using the ESMF bilinear interpolation option and weightfile.  If this pattern doesn't sound any alarms to you and if you have the time to take a look at what we've done, let me know and I can package up the scripts and the data I am trying to work with. I am doing this within ncl so I'm not sure if that limits your ability to diagnose this issue or not so just let me know either way.

Thanks for taking a look,
Dave
